comments.author: Keir Campbell

comments.text:
+Joe Price mmm. lost your crediblility. "which nations improson/execute 
gays" yes, that happens in some Islamic majority countries. but the MUCH 
LARGER, VAST MAJORITY of muslim countries do not do any of those things. 
don't use the extreme versions of Muslim Majority countres as an example of 
what Muslims do.
comments.author: Keir Campbell

comments.text:
+Keir Campbell You're not arguing from an Islamic perspective - you're 
arguing from your own perspective, as does almost every other religious 
person (there are almost as many interpretations as there are people). 

Also, you claim that religions not allowing for gay marriage isn't a form 
of persecution, even though it is a form of discrimination. However, you're 
being extremely dishonest here - the old and new testaments call 
homosexuality an abomination in the eyes of god, and the old testament 
calls for the execution of gays. The same is true of the qu'ran and hadith, 
both of which reference the execution of gays. Countless homosexuals have 
sufferered at the hands of religious tyrants over centuries, and it's only 
recently that there has been tremendous push-back as the rights of 
individuals have started trumping religious beliefs, and the churches have 
started adopting more tolerant views (in no small part to secular laws that 
protect civil liberties of all citizens and curtail discrimination). 

You're accusing me of having a more restrictive secular approach (which is 
good for a laugh coming from a "muslim" blind to the vileness and 
demonstrable immorality of the judeo-christian faiths), and yet tell me - 
do you know which nations imprison or execute gays? 

Here's a nice map of intolance for you, color coded:

http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/02/24/here-are-the-10-countries-where-homosexuality-may-be-punished-by-death/
comments.author: Joe Price

comments.text: +Keir Campbell Nobodies trying to force them to marry gay couples.
comments.author: Rory S. (RoloDolo89)

comments.text:
+Joe Price As to Government over Gods law; i dont see how you dont 
understand me. They can't "override" it. they can FORCE people to act 
accepting of it, but true followers won't just give in to the rule of man 
over God. I'm not suggesting they won't be ABLE to run roughshod just that 
it won't matter .

As for your second bit: there is nothing in my beliefs about killing 
homosexuals. I can't speak for other belief systems as i dont want to speak 
wrongly and misrepresent them.

And as for your last point, i agree. but saying "well sorry our religion 
doesnt allow for same sex marrige" doesn't ostracize ridicule persecute 
maim OR kill them.
Live and let live, and tolerance applies to ALL not just who you think 
deserves it right now.It goes for EVERYONE.  

At some point we're going to come up agianst this point: i argue from the 
Islamic perspective, that all religions and peoples are to be allowed to 
live by their own rules and laws (not really the perspective we see today 
in some Muslim countries but that's not really the RELIGION) and you are 
arguing from the western secular perspective that we all should have one 
set of rules that apply no matter what. i tend to think my way is a bit 
more free and fair and im sure you think the reverse.
comments.author: Keir Campbell

comments.text:
+Keir Campbell Well, I'm afraid now you're losing me on some points. The 
government can and does override god's law (whatever that law happens to be 
- so many interpretations exist). The people of faith can "reject" such 
authority in favor of their god's, as you point out, but in doing so they 
will face the inescapable consequences of their dissent.  As I said, you 
are free to believe what you want, but you are not necessarily free to act 
upon those beliefs, even if you feel that your god permits or even mandates 
that you do so.

You also say persecution of homosexuals is "reprehensible", but in doing so 
you yourself essentially override god's law according to those who hold the 
sincere belief that god views homosexuality as an aberration and that 
homosexuals should be put to death as per the law laid down in Leviticus 
(again, whether that is actually god's law is immaterial - all that matters 
is that someone has the sincerely held belief that it is god's law). You 
cannot have it both ways then. You either respect anyone's beliefs and the 
consequent actions and don't intervene, or you abridge the liberty to act 
on certain beliefs. You elect to do the latter, and I'm with you on that.

Lastly, as a Westerner, I don't have much issue with those of faith "hating 
the sin" as you or they like to call it (I still have a problem with it, 
but it's not a major problem, and one I wouldn't particularly care to 
debate). However, I will always take issue with anyone who acts on such a 
belief in any way that would disparage, ostracize, ridicule, persecute, 
maim, or kill another human being.
comments.author: Joe Price

comments.text:
i think we disagree actually on a lot, for instance that the government CAN 
override the authority of God. the point isn't that some lightnign bolt 
will come down and smite the president if they try to enforce that law. The 
point is the people of that religion will reject any attempt at changing 
it, at usurping Gods word. 
I also think you're confused about where i stand in this: yes, persecution 
of homosexuals is reprehensible. persecution of religion, of skin 
color/culture, of sexual orientation, of ANYTHING is reprehensible. 
But i also don't think that a religion saying "no by our laws we cannot 
approve of or perform an Islamic same sex wedding" is persecution. to FORCE 
them to do it is persecution in my eyes. 
But as you say, we agree on the key points, which are : be nice to people. 
dont hurt them just becuase they love someone with the same parts.
As we say in Islam, you can condemn the sin and still love the sinner. 
(although i must confess being a westerner i don't condemn homosexuality in 
the way most would think, rather i acknowledge the rules laid down in the 
Qur'an. It's up to God to judge, anyway)
But yeah, in general, thanks for being polite and well spoken. We may have 
certain points we agree on, certain points we disagree on, but boy isn't it 
nice to be able to discuss those points like human beings?
comments.author: Keir Campbell

comments.text:
+Keir Campbell Your point that a group would consider god to be a greater 
authority than government is immaterial, because the government can and 
will override that authority if it has a vested interest in doing so (i.e. 
to prevent discrimination against protected classes, or to ensure the 
safety of it's citizens).

What's particularly interesting is that you yourself  speak out against 
actions that would stem from certain sincerely held beliefs (such as 
persecution of homosexuals), because they do not comport with your 
own. Apparently, you do agree then that you in fact do NOT have the right 
to act upon all religious beliefs - only those that don't do damage to 
society.

Also, note that I am making a very important distinction between beliefs 
and actions, and that one should be tolerant through actions, not through 
personal thoughts. The government cannot act as thought police and force 
individuals to accept anyone. However, the government can certainly hold 
accountable any individual that acts on their beliefs, stemming from 
intolerance, in a way that is detrimental to certain citizens or to society 
as a whole.

As such, I think we're almost in agreement on all the key points except the 
loss of tax exemption which you said you still have to consider.
comments.author: Joe Price

comments.text:
+Joe Price again you're missing my point. the government has the authority, 
yeah, but to a religious group that authority is NOTHING to the authority 
of God. "If they do anything that would go against tolerance" well when you 
say tolerance, do you mean raise aggression against for this example 
homosexuals? in that instance i totally agree. We can't let religious 
groups raise any kind of violent aggression towards any group of people for 
differences
But if you mean they 'go against tolerance' as in they don't accept 
behaviors that they truly believe God told them not to accept, then you are 
mistaken in my opinion. Tolerance does not mean acceptance. the tax exempt 
status thing; you may have a point, thats something i'll have to examine 
more to form an opinion on.
comments.author: Keir Campbell

comments.text:
+Keir Campbell Actually, the government does indeed have the authority to 
tell you what you can and cannot practice. Some might, for instance, 
sincerely believe that you must maintain the holy sabbath (it's one of the 
commandments after all) and may even wish to execute those that are in 
violation as per the instructions in Exodus. While anyone can hold such a 
belief, they are not permitted to act upon that belief in any way, 
regardless of whether they feel that their "gods" allowed or even mandated 
such actions. 

Note that the actual interpretation of how to deal with talmudic laws or 
whether they apply to modern society is wholly irrelevant. There is no test 
for the accuracy of one's personal beliefs and whether they even conform to 
scripture - it is only required that they are sincerely-held, and the 
belief holders' imaginations can run wild and free. 

Furthermore, I presented to you a conditional statement - I said that 
churches should be mandated to perform gay/lesbian weddings because of 
their tax-exemption status, which was instituted specifically because 
churches offer valuable community service. If they start doing anything 
that would go against tolerance or create division within communities, then 
they should lose that tax-exemption status.

I do believe that priests shouldn't be compelled to marry anyone, let alone 
gays or lesbians, but those priests should not be exempt from the 
consequences of their choices. They don't live on their own privately owned 
islands along with their congregation - they are part of a secular civil 
society and are expected to give up certain personal freedoms, like the 
rest of us, to maintain tolerance and promote safety and well-being among 
the populace.
comments.author: Joe Price

comments.text:
+Joe Price first off, thank you very much for voicing your opinion in a 
reasonable way making actual POINTS. boy, that's rare on youtube. 
Secondly, i respect that opnion but... in the case of religion, the sins 
are based on judgement of God, indeed. NOT on morals of men or women. That 
is why i full support same sex marriage ion th elegal, secular sense. for 
that same reason, you can't force them to perform them. to religious 
groups, GOD/s HIM/herSELF (as it may apply) has told them these rules. to 
force them to defy them is to say "no you're religion is wrong and not only 
wrong but we have the authority over your mind to tell you what ou may or 
may not believe and /or practice.
comments.author: Keir Campbell

comments.text:
+Keir Campbell I disagree with your position. Churches receive tax 
exemptions because they supposedly offer valuable community services for 
the betterment of society. The government thus has a vested interest in the 
churches spreading messages of tolerance and acceptance for their fellow 
man, and has made the choice of foregoing revenue so that society as a 
whole may benefit. Discriminating against certain citizens goes against 
that. I thus think that the churches should face a choice - be willing to 
marry gays and lesbians, or lose your tax exemption. 

It's time to make the faithful even more tolerant and accepting of fellow 
human beings. Leave the judgment to your gods if you're so certain of other 
people's misdeeds or apparent "sins". Misdeeds or "sins" are labelled as 
such based on the judgment of those very gods, and not based on the 
standards or morals of men and women who have empathy, compasion, and 
possess sound reasoning skills.
comments.author: Joe Price

comments.text:
ahahahhahahahahhahahahhaha that is the most hilarious argument i've ever 
heard. i support their right to their beliefs. I am a Muslim. I believe 
that same sex couples have the right on this world to be treated with 
dignity and respect, and if they wish to be legally married we have no 
authority to deny them that. I have a very very close friend whom i love 
very much whos in a committed lesbian relationship, and if anyone tried to 
deny their life together based on their body parts i would be first to jump 
up in their defense.
That said, i also know that our religion teaches that in the context OF OUR 
RELIGION, same sex marriages are not to be preformed .the right to practice 
your religion is just as important as the right to marry who you want. 
When ti comes down to it, both are the same issue. supporting freedoms of 
people to live however they like, as long as its not going to infringe on 
the rights and safeties of others.

Anyways, if you STILL can't comprehend what i'm saying, you're a lost 
cause. why don't you try getting off tumblr and using your head ?

anyways, im not going to respond any more. either you're actualy this dumb

is, we allow the homosexual person to come into the church and we treat 
them just like everybody else. But just like everybody else, if they have a

sin. In this case, we would show them the following text for one example:

"You shall not lie with a male as with a woman; it is an abomination." 
Leviticus 18:22

But after that, if we know they are persisting in their homosexual 
behavior, two brethren of the faith are to approach them about it and if 
they will not change, they are to be escorted out of the church. At this 
point we would make them aware that we want to see them back but they must 
first change this behavior. Now then, we still love them even after we've 
escorted them out and explained that it is not in our belief to allow 
sinners who are *living* in sin knowingly and consciously to remain in 
attendance.

now, if you don't agree with the above, please note that there are terms of 
endearment for all organizations in life. just as we don't allow the nudist 
to show up nude for church, just like the military doesn't let you wear 
socks on your hands and your gloves on your feet, just like the medical 
doctor doesn't let you play with his MRI machine, just like your parents 
don't let you run out into traffic, just as you don't dance gangnam style

do not agree with these rules that exist before you enter any of these 
organizations or businesses etc., then you shouldn't include yourself 
because we have rules in this life to protect us and keep us safe while

comments.text:
+Temptuous2112
Very good!

Then why did you ask about a "common ancestor between humans and apes"?

What is the common ancestor between robins and birds?

What is the common ancestor between tuna and fish?

What is the common ancestor between dogs and canines?

It's a useless question to ask because robins are birds, tuna are fish, and 
dogs are canines.
comments.author: Paul T Sjordal

comments.text:
+Paul T Sjordal
Humans are classified as apes, specifically great apes.
comments.author: Temptuous2112

comments.text:
+Temptuous2112 
Fine. If humans aren't apes, then what kind of primate are we? Lemurs or 
monkeys?

Or do you deny that we are primates?

Even if we use plain English instead of taxonomy (which is hardly 
arbitrary), robins don't stop being birds because they are robins. Tuna 
does not stop being fish because they are tuna.

The classification of life is hierarchical in English as it is in taxonomy.
comments.author: Paul T Sjordal

comments.text:
+Paul T Sjordal
One again, you are merely describing an arbitrary system of 
classification.   

“Ape” is an English word, and is not a taxonomic term. Taxonomy is 
international everywhere, and recognizes humans as hominoids.
comments.author: Temptuous2112

comments.text:
+Temptuous2112
Evolution is not based on conjecture. It only seems that way to you because 
you carefully avoid examining the evidence and only get your information 
from creationist sources.

Despite what the creationists tell you, evolution is supported by evidence. 
In fact, it is supported by more evidence than any other theory in science.

Sticking your fingers in your ears and screaming "La la la la la!" will not 
make the evidence go away; it only seems to go away from your perspective.

Humans are apes. There is no need to demonstrate common ancestry (although 
we can) to show this.

Dogs do not stop being canines because they are dogs.

Canines do not stop being mammals because they are canines.

Humans are apes. Let's go over the list of differences between monkeys and 
apes (what is said about monkeys also applies to lemurs, the only other 
kind of primate).

Monkeys are smaller, apes are bigger.

Monkeys are dumber, apes are smarter.

Monkeys have tails, apes do not.

Monkeys have less complex social structures, apes have more complex social 
structures.

Some species of ape use tools, monkeys do not.

Humans aren't just apes, we're the apiest apes of all the apes. There is no 
species of ape that is more ape-like than we are.

There are only 3 kinds of primates: apes, monkeys, and lemurs. If you do 
not think humans are apes, do you think we are monkeys? Lemurs?

If you do not think humans are primates, then what category of mammal would 
you place humans in? Bovines? Ovines? Felines? Canines?

Or are you going to deny that humans are mammals? Surely even you aren't 
that extreme.
comments.author: Paul T Sjordal

to understand this, you need to understand Mithocondrial DNA. can you 
google this or do you actually want me to do the work for you?

as for me understanding evolution, ive done so by looking at the research 
and the data. understanding how it works and why it works. its not my 
evidence, its my understanding of the evidence.

and im sorry to say this, but to understand it, you do not just take my 
words for it, a few lines on a youtube commentary, you actually have to 
pick the papers up and read them. 

but i do have a premise about religious people, and that is that 99% of 
them are LAZY couchpotatoes, and to expect them to read science papers and 
work to understand the science behind it. is really problematic, because 
how can i expect someone to read a science paper, when the same lazy 
believer probably have not read their OWN holy bible cover to cover, and 
even if they by a snowballs chance in hell (not the actual hell). that they 
have read it, its not certain that they understands half of it...

and im not here to convert you or convince you. im here to defend my right 
to not be smuthered with your religious Dogma on a daylie basis.
comments.author: Johan Magnusson

comments.text:
+Johan Magnusson
There are no ancient apes that represent a common ancestor.  The premise is 
purely hypothetical. 

It is quite amusing that you make the assertion that you 'understand' the 
evidence without offering any evidence.

You do comprehend what a baseless assertion is?
comments.author: Temptuous2112

comments.text:
+Temptuous2112 yes, as the theory goes its the most plausable theory. we 
are in the category of primates. and we have the mithocandrial DNA tracking 
to follow a string back.

but the ancient apes that we call our ancestors, are not as ape like as you 
wish them to be. and its not that i "believe" it, its that i understand the 
evidence for it. notice UNDERSTAND.

i also understand the reason you want to deny it, because it simply 
contradicts the adam and eve story... and i do not have to ask if you 
believe it... its obvious.

evolution is not something to believe in, its something to be understood 
when accumulated enough information. something im highly positive you have 
not done.

just as i do not believe you have not read your own bible cover to cover.
comments.author: Johan Magnusson

comments.text:
+Paul T Sjordal  phylogenetic's is simply a system of categorization based 
on certain identifying qualities.  To state, without a doubt, that humans 
are indeed apes there would have to be indisputable evidence of a common 
ancestor, and there isn't even one fragment of evidence that a common 
ancestor exists.

Much of evolution is based on conjecture and hypothesis.
comments.author: Temptuous2112

comments.text:
+Temptuous2112
You make it sound like humans aren't apes.

Dog aren't related to canines, they aren't descended from canines, they 
*are* canines.

Canines aren't descended from mammals, they aren't related to mammals, they 
*are* mammals.

Mammals are not descended from vertebrates, nor are they related to 
vertebrates, they *are* vertebrates.

Vertebrates are not descended from animals, they are not related to 
animals, they *are* animals.
comments.author: Paul T Sjordal

comments.text:
+Johan Magnusson "simply because we accept reality and what can be tested".

Do you believe there is a common ancestor for man and ape?
comments.author: Temptuous2112

This may sound sexist but it's actually based on biology - Men have evolved 
to desire a selection, women have evolved to desire a serious one on one.

Man can have his offspring growing in dozens of women
Women can only grow one man's seed, every year (or so).
Nature shows always have the Alpha males fighting to impregnate ALL the 
females
It's never a Lion fighting so he can cop off with a single female and, 
after 3 months of good sex and excitement, spend the rest of his life 
wondering why he got a mortgage with this dull fucking bitch!!!

LOVE - IT's a type of insanity - and it's temporary.
BUT while it's really peaking (first few months) you do insane things, like 
take on staggering amounts of joint debt.
Once the love (chemical hormonal imbalance) calms down, you can't afford to 
keep all the stuff without her half of the cash paying for it...
So you try and forget how boring it is....
Then you start having flings away from home..

Monogamy is biologically unsustainable in males below the age of 76.
